headline.main: Natural Food Is Big, and Sometimes Even Natural

docs.abstract: Marian Burros article on proliferation of natural food supermarkets nationwide, some of which are more 'natural' than others and some of which offer better quality than local supermarkets; assesses some of New York City's leading natural food stores; photos (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: AS confidence in the safety of the commercial food supply has declined in recent years, consumers have increasingly sought their own remedy: the modern natural food store. They believe, right or wrong, that what such stores offer is more healthful, cleaner, safer and higher in quality, and may also be better for the environment. As a result, natural food supermarkets have been springing up around the country like dandelions on a suburban lawn. But as they have increased, they have also evolved. Some are more ''natural'' than others; some offer better quality than local supermarkets, and some don't. In a sense, the stores face the same problem as natural foods themselves: how much is about branding, and how much about delivering what the consumer expects from the name?

headline.main: Even Light Exercise Can Help the Heart

docs.abstract: Harvard Nurses' Health Study, 25-year project, has found that even moderate exercise can help prevent heart disease in women (S)
docs.lead_paragraph: DR. JOANN E. MANSON exercises 20 or 30 minutes every morning on a treadmill or a rowing machine and takes a 10-minute walk every afternoon. She lifts weights for 15 minutes three times a week. Like her fellow investigators on the Harvard Nurses' Health Study -- a 25-year project that has produced a trove of medical findings -- she has become a believer in the preventive power of exercise. But for Dr. Manson, a 48-year-old professor at Harvard Medical School, the great delight in the study's findings about heart disease was the realization that ''no pain, no gain'' is a myth -- that even moderate exercise makes a big difference. The Nurses' Health Study began in 1976, when more than 120,000 nurses filled out questionnaires about their habits and their health. The survey has continued with questionnaires every other year, generating a vast array of information about heart disease, cancer and the effects of lifestyle choices like exercise, diet, alcohol and smoking.

docs.abstract: Cardiologists say many women show little concern about heart disease and its consequences for them; say they are blase about disease that kills many and, contrary to popular belief, tends to work slowly and painfully, turning millions of women's final years into prolonged bout with chest pain, weakness, immobility and shortness of breath; say this endemic lack of awareness is particularly troubling because heart disease, unlike many other diseasess, is becoming more preventable; drawings; map; chart (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: STRESS, of course, is not good for you. But when it comes to heart disease and its consequences, cardiologists say they wish women would feel a little more of it. Never in their memory, doctors say, have so many people been so blasé about a disease that kills so many -- and, contrary to popular belief, tends to work slowly and painfully, turning millions of women's final years into a prolonged bout with chest pain, weakness, immobility and shortness of breath.

headline.main: A Short Fuse Could Be a Time Bomb

docs.abstract: Anger is considered emerging risk factor for heart disease; it may set in motion specific metabolic reaction that clogs arteries; or it may make people smoke and overeat, affecting their blood pressure and cholesterol; landmark study published last year in journal Circulation finds participants with no existing heart disease or hypertension but high anger traits are nearly three times more likely to suffer nonfatal and fatal heart attacks or require bypass surgery than counterparts with less anger; study involved 13,000 men and women; recent study in journal Cardia finds adults age 18 to 30 are more likely to develop calcifications in arteries if they have high hostility ratings; anger management therapy has been found to be helpful; photo; chart (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: BARRY SEIDEL has done a lot of thinking, and he's convinced his explosive temper was a cause of his heart attack last year. A hypercompetitive, self-employed lawyer who often juggled 20 or 30 cases a day, he was 43 when he collapsed one Monday morning at the Queens County Courthouse in New York, with no diabetes, obesity or family history of heart disease. Nothing in particular set off the attack, he recalls; what stands out was that anger had become his reflexive response to stress. By his own account, he would morph into a yeller, a fist-clencher, a vein-popper. ''I did more than once throw the phone and pick up a book and throw it against the wall to the point where it scared my employees,'' he said.
